turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Just -- flawed.  Very deeply flawed.

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: Why did you come here?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: So that others would know about this place?

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: Why should they?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Because it exists.

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: It'll still exit if they go on not knowing, won't it?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Yes.  And people will live in the absence of truth.

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: So the truth is more important to you than your life?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I don't care about my life.  But if I'd ever thought for a second that she would be in danger --

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: Somewhere on this island, there exits the greatest predator that ever lived.  And the second greatest predator must take him down.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: But why?

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: You remember that guy, about twenty years ago, I forget his name, but he climbed Everest without any oxygen, came down almost dead.  And they asked him, "why did you go up there to die?"  And he said "I didn't.  I went up there to live."

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: It's called self-testing.  But in your case, it sounds more like self-destruction.  A uniquely human characteristic.  In fact, human beings destroy things so well that I sometimes think that's our function. Maybe every few sons, some animal comes along that kills off the rest of the world, clears the decks, and lets evolution proceed to his next phase.  Maybe death and destruction are our job, maybe we're supposed to destroy ourselves and every other living thing that-

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: How many rounds did you find for that weapon?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Four, counting the one in the chamber.

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: Don't let it out of your hands again.  Can the kid walk?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You gentlemen feel you have to do this now?

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: Now's the perfect time.  The animal just fed, so it won't stalk us for food.  Predators don't hurt when they're not hungry.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No more smoking.  We leave no scent of any kind.  No hair tonics, no cologne, seal all our food in plastic bags.  We will observe and document, but we will not interact.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: That's a scientific impossibility, you know.  Heisenberg uncertainty principle.  Whatever you study, you also change.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You know you were putting yourself in a potentially dangerous situation, but you didn't bother to find out how dangerous before you leapt in. You don't have the faintest idea what's going on on this island!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What do you want to do, Ian, lock her up for curiosity?  Where do you think she gets it?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: You're going home.  I'm sending a radio call for the boats.  We'll all go down to the lagoon and wait for them.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Lighten up, Ian, you sound like a high school vice-principal.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: I'm her father.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: No!  We're an independently funded expedition.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Funded by whom?

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: John Hammond.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Can you set up?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: It has to be temporary, something that'll break apart and fall off as the animal grows...

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Think fast, Sarah.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: That's impossible, they can't have the sensory equipment to track it all the way here!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Current evidence seems to be to the contrary, wouldn't you say?!  GIVE IT TO THEM!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Born free, as free as the wind blows. As free as the grass grows --

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Are you insane?!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I swear to God, it works with lions sometimes!  There we are -- your baby is free --

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: All right.  I'm satisfied with the evidence we have right now. I feel vindicated.  John Hammond will too.  Do you have enough to publish?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: They will come after me.  But I can collect some stool samples, for DNA with that, Nick's tapes, and the rest of you to back me up, it should stand when we get back.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Then the only thing left to do is make sure we do get back.  I'll call the mainland on the satellite phone and have them send the boat right now.  This expedition is over.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Oh, God.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: They're pushing us over the cliff.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You know, even if we do get those tapes back, people are going to say it's just another hoax.  Ian Malcolm's alien autopsy.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Maybe.  Maybe not.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Ian, they will misplace our evidence, shoot holes in our testimony, and say some special effects genius created the animals.  The only way people will ever believe that dinosaurs exist is if you dump a T-rex in the middle of times Square.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Ian.  It's guano.

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: These formations.  They're dried --

turns.speaker: MALCOLM
turns.text: Birdshit?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: So what's your story, Nick?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I was a cameraman for Nightline for six years, been freelance since '91. Do a lot of work for Greenpeace.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: That must be interesting.  What drew you there?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Women.  'Bout eighty percent female in Greenpeace.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Very noble of you.  You don't think you're bringing that thing onto the island, do you?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Hey, I wouldn't want to spook the woolly mammoths.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You think this is all a joke?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Oh, please.  How am I supposed to keep a straight face when --  -- Johnny Cash here tells me I'm going to Skull Island?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Ian's a very good friend of mine.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: He doesn't need a friend, he needs a shrink.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: I believe in him.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: -- way we could safely --

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Oh, no!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: The kid scores with cheap sentiment.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Ian, if we recall the boat now, we've made two invasive landings in one day.  That'll have to go in any paper I write, and it will leave room for people to say our findings were contaminated.  You know the academic world as well as I do, once they smell blood in the water, you're dead.  Our presence has got to be one hundred percent antiseptic.  That means if we bend a blade of grass, we bend it right back the way it-

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Ruining everything, that's what they're doing.  You could choke on the diesel smoke already!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Ian, nothing we observe will be valid if we're trailing along in the wake of an army.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: That little black line?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: That little black line means death for this infant.  The fibula won't heal straight, so the ankle joint can't pivot when he stands on his hind feet.  The baby won't be able to run, and probably can't even walk. It'll be crippled, and a predator will pick it off before it gets more than a few weeks old.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Give it more morphine!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: We'll kill it with too much, we'll put it into respiratory arrest!  I'm almost done.  Damn it, I need another adhesive, something pliable I can --

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Hold it down, Nick!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I'm trying!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: There's, uh -- there's an unwritten rule when a news crew is in a war zone.  You stop the van every two miles and decide whether or not to go on.  Whether or not you feel lucky. One "no" from anybody in the group and you turn around right there, no question asked, nobody embarrassed.  Well?  Do we go on? Immediately:

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: WHAT ARE YOU-

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: JUMP!

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Where's Kelly?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Where's Ian?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Hey, we came here to observe, you came here to strip-mine the place! It's a looter mentality, all you care about is what you can take.

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: None of that matters.  Our communications equipment's been destroyed.  If your radio and satellite phone were in those trailers that went off the cliff, and I'm guessing by the look on his face --

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: If we can't stay in the rex's territory, we have to move tonight.

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Move where?  Our boat's not coming for two days, your airlift is waiting for an order you have no way to send --

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: We have to send someone to look for him!

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: You go if you like, but we're not waiting for you.  MOVE IT OUT!!

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: Ask her.

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: Can the kid walk?

turns.speaker: SARAH
turns.text: You've got to be kidding.

turns.speaker: ROLAND
turns.text: Runs against my nature to hole up in a cave and wait.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Uh - - Mr. Hammond - -

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Stop the program!  Stop the program!

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: That storm center hasn't dissipated or changed course. We're going to have to cut the tour short, I'm afraid. Pick it up again tomorrow where we left off.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: You're sure we have to?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: It's not worth taking the chance, John.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Ladies and gentlemen, last shuttle to the dock leaves in approximately five minutes.  Drop what you are doing and leave now.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Damn!

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: I found a way to re-route through the program.  I'm turning the cars around in the rest area loop.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Rotten luck, this storm.  Get my grandchildren on the radio will you?  I don't want them to worry about a wee bit of rain.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Visitor vehicles are on their way back to the garage.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: So how much for our first tour.  Two no-shows and one sick triceratops.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: It could have been worse, John.  It could have been a lot worse.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: The door security systems are shutting down.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Well, Nedry said a few systems would go off-line, didn't he?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Woah, woah, woah, what the hell, what the hell?

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: What now?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Fences are failing, all over the park!  A few minor systems, he said!

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Find Nedry!  Check the vending machines!

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: The monitors are failing.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Phones are out too.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Where did the vehicles stop?

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: We're talking, my dear, about a calculated risk, which is the only option left to us.  We will never find the command NEDRY used.  He covered his tracks far too well, and I think it's obvious he's not coming back.  So shutting down the system - -

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: I will not do it.  You'll have to get somebody else, because I will not.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: - - shutting down the system is the only way to guarantee wiping out everything he did. If I understand correctly, all the system will come back on their original start-up modes correct?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Theoretically, yeah , but we've never shut down the whole system.  It may not come back at all.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Are we getting anywhere with these procedures of yours? I mean, what's hanging us up?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: I ran a key check on every stroke Nedry entered today. It's all pretty standard stuff, until this one - -

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What one?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: How many lines of code are there?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Uh - - about two million.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Two million - - great.  That would help.  Oh good, that'll take no time.

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: No, no, no, that's crazy, you're out of your mind, he's absolutely out of his mind - -

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Wait a minute.  What exactly does this mean?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But would we get the phones back?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: Yeah, again, in  theory, but - -

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: The lysine contingency - it's intended to prevent the spread of the animals is case they ever got off the island, but we could use it now.  Dr. Wu inserted a gene that makes a single faulty enzyme in protein metabolism. Animals can't manufacture the amino acid lysine.  Unless they're continually supplied with lysine by us, they'll go into a coma and die.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: How would we cut off the lysine?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: No trick to it.  Just stop running the program.  Leaving them unattended.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: How long will this take?

turns.speaker: ARNOLD
turns.text: 'Bout thirty seconds.

turns.speaker: DODGSON
turns.text: You shouldn't use my name.

turns.speaker: NEDRY
turns.text: Dodgson, Dodgson.  We got Dodgson here!  See, nobody cares.  Nice hat. What are you trying to look like, a secret agent?

turns.speaker: NEDRY
turns.text: Oh, I'll get 'em all.

turns.speaker: DODGSON
turns.text: Remember - - viable embryos.  They're no use to us if they don't survive.

turns.speaker: NEDRY
turns.text: How am I supposed to transport them?

turns.speaker: NEDRY
turns.text: What?  No menthol?

turns.speaker: DODGSON
turns.text: Mr Nedry, Mr Nedry.  The embryos have to be back here in San Jose by then.

turns.speaker: NEDRY
turns.text: That's up to your guy on the boat.  Seven o'clock tomorrow night, at the east dock. Make sure he got it right.

turns.speaker: DODGSON
turns.text: I was wondering, how are you planning to beat the security?

turns.speaker: NEDRY
turns.text: I got an eighteen minute window.  Eighteen minutes, and your company catches up on ten years of research.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Paleo-DNA?  From what source?  Where do you get 100 million year old dinosaur blood?!

turns.speaker: GENNARO
turns.text: Shhhhh!

turns.speaker: GENNARO
turns.text: Please - - let's hear something from the others.  Dr. Grant?  I am sorry - - Dr. Sattler?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The question is - - how much can you know about an extinct ecosystem, and therefore, how could you assume you can control it?  You have plants right here in this building, for example, that are poisonous.  You picked them because they look pretty, but these are aggressive living things that have no idea what century they're living in and will defend themselves.  Violently, if necessary.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Alan?  Where are we going?  You see something?

turns.speaker: GENNARO
turns.text: Uh - - anybody else think we shouldn't be out here?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yours was fully illustrated, honey.

turns.speaker: GENNARO
turns.text: Anybody at all.  Feel free to speak up.

turns.speaker: GENNARO
turns.text: Doctors, if you please - - I have to insist we get moving.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, you know, if it's alright, I'd like to stay with Dr. Harding and finish with the trike.  Is that okay?

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: Imbalance, disorientation, labored breathing.  Seems to happen about every six weeks or so.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Six weeks?

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: Yes, mitotic, pupils should be constricted.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: These are dilated.  Take a look.

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: They are?  I'll be damned.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That's pharmacological.  From local plant life.

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: Yes.  We know they're toxic, but the animals don't eat them.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: Pretty sure.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: There's only one way to be positive.  I need to see some droppings.  I have to see the dinosaur's droppings.

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: You won't be able to miss them.  Can't miss them.

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: Sure.  I've got a gas powered jeep.  I can drop her at the visitor's center before I make the boat with the others.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'll catch up with you.  You can go with the others.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Did I say jerk?

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: I'm sorry for the dramatic entrance, but I'm in a hurry. Will you have a wee bit of a drink now and then?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I have samples all over the kitchen.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Come along.  I know my way around a kitchen.  Come along.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: There you are.  Out you come.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh my God.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Could I have a tissue please?

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Fascinating animals, fascinating.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh my God.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Give time, they'll out draw the T-rex.  Guarantee it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Alan, these aren't bones anymore.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: We're - - still perfecting a viewing system.  The raptors seem to be a bit resistant to integration into a park setting.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Malcolm's okay for now.  I gave him a shot of morphine.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: They'll all be fine.  Who better to get the children through Jurassic Park than a dinosaur expert?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Carousel.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: A carousel - - and a seesaw.  They all moved, motorized of course, but people would swear they could see the fleas.  "I see the fleas, mummy!  Can't you see the fleas?" Clown fleas, high wire fleas, fleas on parade...

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: But with this place, I - - I wanted to give  them something real, something that wasn't an illusion, something they could see and  touch.  An aim devoid of  merit.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But you can't think through this one.  You have to feel it.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: You're absolutely right.  Yes, you're right.  Hiring Nedry was a mistake, that's obvious.  	We're over- dependent on automation, I can see that now.  But that's all correctable for the next time around.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: John, John.  John, you're still building onto that Flea Circus, that illusion.  And now you're adding onto it by what you're doing here.  That's the illusion.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Once we have control again we - -

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Control?!  You never had control!  I was overwhelmed by the power of this place.  So I made a mistake too.  I didn't have enough respect for that power, and it's out now.  You're sitting here trying to pick up the pieces. John, there's nothing worth picking up.  The only thing that matters now are the people we love.  Alan, Lex, and Tim.  And John, they're out there where people are dying - - people are dying, you know?

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: This is just a delay, that's all this is.  All major theme parks have had delays.  When they opened Disneyland in 1956, nothing worked, nothing.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: John....

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: But you know, I should  really be the one going .

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Well, because you're a - - I'm a - -

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Look.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Mr. Arnold?  He's not answering me.  Okay I'm on the grating.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Good!  Keep going, now.  The cable will terminate in a big, gray box.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Okay, I'm following the tubing.  I'm going down a passage way.  How long does this stuff go for?  Could you guys talk a little bit to me?

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Four complete skeletons. . . . such a small area. . . the same time horizon - -

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: They died together?

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: The taphonomy sure looks that way.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: If they died together, they lived together. Suggests some kind of social order.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: A drought.  The lake was shrinking - -

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: That's good.  That's right!  They died around a dried-up puddle!  Without fighting each other.  This is looking good.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Postmortem contraction of the posterior neck ligaments.  Velociraptor?

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Yes.  Good shape, too.  Five, six feet high.  I'm guessing nine feet long.  Look at the - -

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You know, if you really wanted to scare the kid you could've just pulled a gun on him.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Yeah, I know, you know...kids.  You want to have one of those?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well, not one of those, well yeah, a possibly one at some point could be a good thing.  What's so wrong with kids?

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Oh, Ellie, look.  They're noisy, they're messy, they're sticky, they're expensive.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Cheap, cheap, cheap.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: They smell.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh my god, they do not!  They don't smell.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: They do smell.  Some of them smell.. babies smell.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Alright, the one on the airplane had an accident, but usually babies don't smell.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: They know very little about the Jurassic Period they know less about the Cretaceous.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The what?

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: The Cretaceous.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Anything else, you old fossil?

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Yeah, plenty.  Some of them can't walk!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It frustrates me so much that I love you, that I need to strangle you right now!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Okay, who's the jerk?

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Uh, this is our paleobotanist, Dr Ellie.....

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Sattler.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: And what are those?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Small versions of adults, honey.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why would they care what we think?

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: What kind of park is it?

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: The movement!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The - - agility.  You're right!

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Ellie, we can tear up the rule book on cold-bloodedness. It doesn't apply, they're totally wrong!  This is a warm-blooded creature.  They're totally wrong.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: They were wrong.  Case closed.  This thing doesn't live in a swamp to support it's body weight for God's sake!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You've got a T-rex!?  He's got a T-rex!  A T-rex!  He said he's- -

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Say again?

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Ellie, they're absolutely - - they're moving in herds. They do move in herds!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: We were right!

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: How did you do it?!  How did you do this?!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: So what are you thinking?

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: We're out of a job.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Wait a minute!  How do you interrupt the cellular mitosis?!?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Can't we see the unfertilized host eggs?!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh, shit.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Dilophosaurus.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Oh Ellie.  It's so beautiful.  It's the most beautiful thing I ever saw.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's my favorite.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Ellie, I've been thinking there's something about the periodicity doesn't had up.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Constantly sick.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Not just every six weeks.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yeah, I know.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Elm that's it, it explains the periodicity, the - -

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: - - the undigested state of the berries because it's - -

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: - - totally incidental  unrelated to the feeding pattern - -

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: - - like birds - -

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: - - like birds.  What happen is, they swallow the stones and hold them in a muscular sack in their stomachs - -

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: - - a gizzard - -

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: - - which is called a gizzard, and it helps them mash their food, but what happens after a while - -

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: - - what happens is that after a while, the stones get smooth, every six weeks, so the animal regurgitates them - -

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: - - barfs them up - -

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: - - and swallows fresh ones.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And when she swallows the stones, she swallows the poison berries too.  That's what makes her sick.  Good work Tim.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'll just finish.  Yeah, I want to finish.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: It's just the two raptors, right?  You're sure the third one's contained?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes, unless they figured out how to open doors.

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Ellie - - get back and boot up the door locks!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You can't hold it by yourself!

turns.speaker: GRANT
turns.text: Ellie, get the gun!  Try to reach the gun!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I can't get it!  I can't get it unless I move!

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: They show extreme intelligence, even problem solving. Especially the big one.  We bred eight originally, but when she came in, she took over the pride and killed all but two of the others.  That one - -when she looks at you, you can see she's thinking  working things out.  She's the reason we have to feed 'em like this. She had them all attacking the fences when the feeders came.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The fences are electrified, right?

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: That's right.  But they never attack the same place twice.  They were testing the fences for weaknesses. Systematically.  They remembered.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Dr. Sattler, I've seen a lot of animal attacks.  People just disappear.  No blood, no trace.  	That's the way it happens.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No, no, no!

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Ellie, com one!!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The other car!

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Dr. Grant!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Alan!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Do you see anything?

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Alan?!

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: They're not here.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: What about the lysine contingency?  We could put that into effect!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I can't wait anymore.  Something went wrong.  I'm going to go get the power back on.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: You can't just stroll down the road, you know.
